title: Credit card borrowing falls to lowest level since December
text:
Figures from the Bank of England showed that credit card borrowing fell to £200m in August

Credit card borrowing fell to its lowest level since December in a sign consumers are reining in spending.

Figures from the Bank of England showed that borrowing fell to £200million in August, £100million less than in July.

The Bank also reported the outstanding value of consumer loans – credit cards plus bank loans and other advances – fell to £900million in August.

This figure was consistently above the £1.5billion mark in 2016-17, but has averaged £1billion in the last year.

The number of mortgage approvals being made to home-buyers also fell back in August from an 18-month high seen the previous month.

Some 65,545 mortgage approvals were made for house purchases in August, down from 67,011 in July.

It came as the Office for National Statistics confirmed the economy shrank 0.2 per cent in the second quarter to June, explaining this was partly due to uncertainty over Brexit.

The economy is at risk of going into recession – defined as two consecutive quarters of contraction.

But Howard Archer, chief economic adviser at EY Item Club, said Britain will avoid recession, predicting a return to growth in the third quarter.

However the gloom is reflected in the financial services sector, where confidence is diving at the fastest pace since the crisis of 2008, the CBI said.
description: New figures from the Bank of England showed that borrowing fell to £200m in August, £100m less than in July. The Bank also reported the outstanding value of consumer loans fell to £0.9bn in August.
